question: You are a code expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Be careful to ensure that any code you generate is executable. Please implement an AI-based audio restoration tool where users can upload audio files containing noise, distortion, or poor sound quality, and the system will automatically detect and repair these issues through algorithms. The tool should provide functions such as noise reduction, distortion repair, volume normalization, and audio quality enhancement, and allow users to adjust the repair intensity through parameters. The interface should display before-and-after waveform comparisons, allowing users to visually experience the restoration effects.

checklist.title: Is the audio upload and handling functionality properly implemented?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code includes a robust mechanism for uploading audio files (supporting common formats like MP3, WAV, FLAC, OGG), proper validation of file types and sizes, and error handling for corrupt files. Check if the audio processing pipeline correctly decodes the audio for further manipulation with proper memory management. Score 0 if basic upload is missing, 5 if only basic formats are supported without validation, and 10 if comprehensive upload handling with proper error management is implemented.

checklist.title: How comprehensive are the AI-based audio restoration algorithms?
checklist.description: Review the implementation of core restoration algorithms including: 1) Noise reduction (spectral gating, adaptive noise filtering), 2) Distortion repair (harmonic analysis, clipping restoration), 3) Volume normalization (RMS/LUFS standards compliance), and 4) General quality enhancement (frequency response correction, dynamic range processing). Deduct 3 points for each missing algorithm. Award full points only if implementations include proper signal processing principles with AI integration (ML models, neural networks, or advanced DSP techniques).

checklist.title: Is the parameter adjustment system user-friendly and effective?
checklist.description: Assess whether users can adjust repair intensity through intuitive controls (sliders, knobs) for each restoration function with appropriate ranges and defaults. Check if real-time preview capability exists, parameter presets are available, and tooltips explain each parameter's function. Deduct 5 points if adjustments don't produce audible differences in output, 3 points if controls lack visual feedback, and 2 points if parameter ranges are inappropriate for their functions.

checklist.title: How effective is the before-and-after waveform visualization?
checklist.description: Evaluate the quality of waveform rendering showing both original and processed audio. Check for synchronized playback indicators, zoom functionality, highlighting of modified sections, and ability to switch between waveform/spectrogram views. Waveforms should update in real-time when parameters change. Deduct 5 points if visualizations aren't accurate representations of the audio data, 3 points if comparative analysis tools are missing, and 2 points if the visualization isn't responsive to user interaction.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle common abnormal situations (such as corrupted audio files, extremely noisy inputs, browser compatibility issues, memory limitations with large files) and provide friendly error prompts or recovery mechanisms. Code with strong robustness should be able to effectively handle these edge cases, giving 10 points. If the robustness is average, give 5 points, and if no exceptions are handled, give 0 points.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that are eye-catching?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes surprise features that enhance the experience (e.g., 1. AI-based content identification 2. Automatic detection of optimal restoration settings 3. Batch processing capabilities 4. Export with restoration history metadata). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant implementation of similar audio processing algorithms 2. Function modules unrelated to audio restoration (e.g., unnecessary media playback features) 3. Computationally expensive visualizations that affect performance without adding value. Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if the core functions are interfered with by redundant code.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (such as separating audio processing logic/UI/file handling layers), unit test coverage for processing algorithms, and build process automation. Deduct 5 points if global state pollution is found or design patterns are not used; deduct 5 points if the code duplication rate is too high (over 30%); deduct 5 points if the build process is not automated or audio processing workloads aren't properly optimized. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet professional design standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the overall design follows modern design principles: 1) Harmonious color matching (no more than 3 primary colors) 2) Proper layout spacing (element spacing follows the 8px multiple principle) 3) Professional font system (body font size ≥ 14px, line height over 1.5 times). Deduct 3 points for each crowded visual element, 5 points for a glaring color combination, and 5 points for chaotic text-image layout. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the dynamic interaction smooth and seamless?
checklist.description: Judge whether the dynamic effects conform to human perception characteristics: 1) Parameter adjustment feedback delay ≤ 100ms 2) Transition animation duration controlled between 300-500ms 3) Clear visual indication of processing status during heavy computations. Deduct 5 points for each operation without feedback, 3 points for laggy audio preview during parameter changes, and 5 points for unclear indication of when processing is complete. The full score is 10 points.
